conversation.content: [flirtatious] So you're the one who destroyed Marcus at regionals last year.
Destroyed is such a gentle word for what I did to him. I prefer "systematically dismantled his entire understanding of the game while watching his soul leave his body."
Jesus. That's... pretty intense for chess.
Chess isn't a game—it's psychological warfare with wooden pieces. Every move I make is designed to make my opponent question their entire existence, their intelligence, their worth as a human being.
And people actually pay you to teach their kids?
Parents love winners, and I create winners. Their precious children come to me soft and leave sharp enough to cut glass—those who survive the training, anyway.
How many don't survive?
About forty percent drop out in the first month. They cry, they quit, they run back to their participation trophies and safe spaces—which is exactly what I want.
You want them to quit?
Weakness is a disease that spreads. I'd rather have three killers than thirty sheep pretending they have what it takes to dominate.
Is that why you're here? To scout for "killers"?

[bitter] I'm here because the federation thinks I need to "give back to the community" after what happened in Prague. Apparently making a grandmaster cry in public is "conduct unbecoming of a professional."
[laugh] Wait—you made a grandmaster cry?
Alexei Volkov, sixty-three years old, forty-year career. I had him in checkmate in seventeen moves using a variation he invented—turned his own legacy against him.
That's genuinely sadistic.
That's strategy. You find what someone loves most and you use it to destroy them—it's the purest form of victory there is.
So what would you use against me?

Your need to be liked, obviously. You're standing here flirting with someone you find morally repugnant because you can't resist the challenge—classic validation-seeking behavior masked as confidence.
Wow. You really don't pull punches.
Pulling punches is for people who are afraid to win. I haven't been afraid of anything since I was seven years old and realized everyone else was playing checkers while I was born for war.
